post:
How do you all lose weight?
I’ve tried many different diets for weight loss but I feel like every time I even slightly cut carbs my body is constantly in the 70-90 zone. I’m trying to lose about twenty pounds and I’ve taken up running to help. But still I need to find a way to have a better diet. With out constantly crashing my BG. Could I replace carbs with things like honey?

comments.text: The 70-90 zone is perfect. That is nearly exactly where a non-diabetic’s blood sugar resides and a great goal. I follow Dr Bernstein’s Diabetes Solution as closely as possible which is low carb with basically that blood sugar range as the goal.

Honey is a carb. It's literally sugar.

70-90 is perfectly fine and once you adjust to having a lower baseline, you won't feel "low,"

Basically, losing weight is the same as for anyone else; use more calories than you take in. But with diabetes, you have another way to look at it that I've found helpful: Anything that lets you use less insulin while keeping your blood sugars in range will help. Moving more, eating fewer empty carbs and drinking adequate water in combination will help you eventually shed pounds. Add some weight lifting if you want to see an improvement in insulin sensitivity too.

I did weight watchers for a bit and it worked wonderfully! It kept my numbers in a great range and it helped me lose some stubborn weight. Because of the great options for fruits and veggies that you can have I found that I was able to stay away from going low too frequently
Have you adjusted your basal down a tad if you’re constantly eating less and exercising?
You're on the right track! But you have to lower you basal insulin to prevent the blood sugar crashes.
👏send 👏yourself 👏into 👏dka 👏it 👏isn’t 👏that 👏hard 👏 jk

claims: honey is a carb.
it's literally sugar.
anything that lets you use less insulin while keeping your blood sugars in range will help.
add some weight lifting if you want to see an improvement in insulin sensitivity too.
have you adjusted your basal down a tad if you’re constantly eating less and exercising?
you have to lower you basal insulin to prevent the blood sugar crashes.
the 70-90 zone is perfect. that is nearly exactly where a non-diabetic’s blood sugar resides and a great goal.

post: Can't wait for tomorrow. to see what the fuck happens when I sleep .First time using dexom ,been using libre forever. I couldn't get the first one right . random tips are welcomed

comments.text: Why did you redact your bellybutton?_ I don't think anyone on the internet is gonna identify you by your bellybutton

If you sleep on your side, beware of compression lows. Apparently, this happens, when the sensor gets pushed against the body which results to false low reading in reader/app

Hence why it's called compression lows
Dirty belly button? Ugly belly button? Shy about posting your belly button?
The first 6 hours after the first warm up are trash. They are wildly inaccurate. Try to calibrate it first thing in the morning before food!

Another tip that came to my mind, if you want more accurate readings, 

Put a new sensor in 24 hrs before the current one expires. Once the main one expires start the other sensor that you inserted earlier.
calabrate once a day. try not to sleep directly on it. my daughters gets extremely false lows due to where we originally placed it

Presoaking sensors is the only way I can get mine accurate. I insert a sensor the night before I’m going to activate it so it’s in my body for 8 hours, then I activate it the next morning. I learned that from this sub a while ago.

claims: if you sleep on your side, beware of compression lows. apparently, this happens, when the sensor gets pushed against the body which results to false low reading in reader/app
the first 6 hours after the first warm up are trash. they are wildly inaccurate. try to calibrate it first thing in the morning before food!
calabrate once a day. try not to sleep directly on it.
presoaking sensors is the only way i can get mine accurate. i insert a sensor the night before i’m going to activate it so it’s in my body for 8 hours, then i activate it the next morning.

post:
How to bring up Ozempic when talking to your doctor 
I have an upcoming appointment with my endocrinologist and I want to be put on Ozempic/other brands for weight loss and better control of my A1c. I am 23f and have been t1d since I was 9. I have gained a decent amount of weight in the last 1.5 year half even though I haven’t changed any eating/lifestyle habits that I am aware of. I use a lot of insulin daily for basal and bolus on my Omnipod, and I think Ozempic will help me both lose weight and manage my diabetes better. I am unsure of the best way to bring this up without sounding like everyone else begging for it or being dismissed. I have read mixed reviews, stating that it can help T1Ds but also ones that it can be harmful for them. What is the best way to talk to my doctor about this and what are your opinions on Ozempic while having t1d?

comments.text: Hey doc. I'd like to try ozempic.
Exactly like you just did in this post!

I’m a type 1 on mounjaro. My dr actually recommended it to me to help with peaks after eating. I’m 165 lbs so not really overweight but it has helped me control that also. 
I should add I’m honeymooning so mounjaro has replaced my need for meal time insulin. I’m taking long acting still.

Bring up insulin resistance more than weight if you think that might be the best angle for you. My endo actually brought ozempic up to me 3 1/2 years ago for weight loss *because I was using so much insulin* that she thought it could only help. In 3 1/2 years I’ve lost 115lbs and it’s truly game changing.

I took Ozempic for 9 months until I couldn’t find it anymore and then I switched to a compounded Mounjaro. I got it through telehealth because I was embarrassed to ask my endo for it. Ironically when I went for an appt about 3 months after starting, he said “you are the only person today who hasn’t asked me for Mounjaro.” I didn’t fess up to being on it already. He said “just message me if you want to try it. It’s amazing” and while I appreciate that, I don’t think I was THAT fat to warrant him straight up offering but here we are. I’m 53lbs smaller now and no longer obese. 🤣 
All that to say, everyone is asking them for it all day long. Just ask!

I'm on Ozempic, prescribed by my endo and fully covered by my insurance. When I asked her if I could try it, I explained I had great success taking Symlin for about a year a long time ago to help with meal spikes, but it burned like crazy and my legs were so beat up that I stopped. It also had some pretty negative hypoglycemia aspects, which is why it's a banned med for pilots.

Anyway, my endo said she would put all her type 1s on Ozempic if she could, but she doesn't suggest it for everyone  yet because people are still struggling with insurance coverage.

Two weeks ago I emailed my doctor, asking for help with losing weight. I quit smoking and gained 25 pounds, I was already 20 pounds overweight. She responded she sent prescription for ozempic to pharmacy. That easy

You have no idea how happy I am to have found this post. I was going to make one just like it and our backgrounds are literally the same. I have been using so much more insulin lately and it is scaring me. I also gained so much weight in the last 2 years and I don't really know why. I have an appointment in a week and hopefully, my doctor is willing to prescribe this for me.

claims: my endo actually brought ozempic up to me 3 1/2 years ago for weight loss *because i was using so much insulin* that she thought it could only help.
my endo said she would put all her type 1s on ozempic if she could, but she doesn't suggest it for everyone  yet because people are still struggling with insurance coverage.

post:
How much does working out help?
I’ve been living with T1D since I was 16 (23 now) and was always active in high school and even post school, but now that I’m working and married I don’t have much time to work out. I have always been good about my levels I shoot for 130 as a goal and absolutely fall apart if my sugar gets above 230. I feel like I’ve been  injecting so much just to keep it in check. I swear I eat a sandwich and chips and I’m having to take 15 units of novalog just to not sky rocket!  I’m thinking is it because of my body just not breakdown anything because of the lack of exercise? How often should I be going to the gym a week/what exercises? Any help would be greatly appreciated.

comments.text: Working out definitely helps alot! The more you exercise you can help increase your insulin sensitivity for the hours afterwards and thus you would probably need to be using less insulin per day. However, some people do tend to see BG raises during workouts because of the stress it puts on your body, Id definitely recommend beginning a workout program, starting off slow at 2-3 times per week until you start to get more used to it . It will definitely be beneficial in the long run.

Working out helps a lot with insulin resistance. I recommend just starting out with cardio. Start with something that keeps your heart rate between 130-160 for 30 minutes to 1 hour. Weight lifting is also good and can actually sometimes increase your blood sugar due to your muscles needing more glucose. As I’m sure you know, routines are a great thing when it comes to diabetes management. If you can work out consistently, that will help too. The most important thing I can tell you is to check your blood sugar before and after a workout. Don’t be shy to even check during your workout. Reach out to a personal trainer for whatever your goal is specifically. But any workout of any kind should help with your problem, good luck!
Walking 15000 steps a day definitely helps keep my blood sugar in check.  I also eat a vegan starch centered whole foods eating choice.  Processed foods  wreck havoc on my blood sugars.
An insane amount. Always be in good shape with type 1. If I work out a lot my BS is solid 100 a lot.

When I work out it definitely helps with insulin sensitivity although I usually have to inject before a workout. 
I also low carb and there is no way on earth that only 15 units would ever even come close to covering a sandwich and a bag of chips! Ditch the carbs! If we already can’t process sugar like normal people why would you put sugar into your body and not expect a disaster?

So so so much. It is night and day for me. Working out helps with insulin sensitivity and blood sugars but also with the stuff that can come along with diabetes (depression, anxiety, weight issues). I consider my gym membership to be part of my “non-negotiable” must-haves for this reason. I personally work out hard four days a week (Orangetheory) and stay fairly active the other days (long walks, chasing my toddler around, etc.) the other days. The best exercise plan is one you enjoy and stick with over time!

claims: the more you exercise you can help increase your insulin sensitivity for the hours afterwards and thus you would probably need to be using less insulin per day.
the more you exercise you can help increase your insulin sensitivity for the hours afterwards and thus you would probably need to be using less insulin per day.

working out helps a lot with insulin resistance. i recommend just starting out with cardio. start with something that keeps your heart rate between 130-160 for 30 minutes to 1 hour. weight lifting is also good and can actually sometimes increase your blood sugar due to your muscles needing more glucose.

working out helps a lot with insulin resistance. i recommend just starting out with cardio. start with something that keeps your heart rate between 130-160 for 30 minutes to 1 hour. weight lifting is also good and can actually sometimes increase your blood sugar due to your muscles needing more glucose. as i’m sure you know, routines are a great thing when it comes to diabetes management. if you can work out consistently, that will help too. the most important thing i can tell you is to check your blood sugar before and after a workout. don’t be shy to even check during your workout. reach out to a personal trainer for whatever your goal is specifically. but any workout of any kind should help with your problem, good luck!
working out helps a lot with insulin resistance.
when i work out it definitely helps with insulin sensitivity although i usually have to inject before a workout

so so so much. it is night and day for me. working out helps with insulin sensitivity and blood sugars but also with the stuff that can come along with diabetes (depression, anxiety, weight issues). i consider my gym membership to be part of my “non-negotiable” must-haves for this reason. i personally work out hard four days a week (orangetheory) and stay fairly active the other days (long walks, chasing my toddler around, etc.) the other days. the best exercise plan is one you enjoy and stick with over time!

post:
Explaining the honeymoon
How does one explain going into a honeymoon phase?  I was diagnosed two months ago, but now I’m off all insulin-which is great-but no one seems to understand.  Mostly I’m getting “so you’re not diabetic anymore” or “ I knew that you were just being dramatic about Covid giving you diabetes. Your diagnosis was clearly a mistake.”

comments.text: I’d stop trying to explain things to people who aren’t listening.

When you are first diagnosed your pancreas usually still has some beta cells left. But they are usually almost burned out because they were working in overdrive trying to keep your blood sugar in check. When you introduce artificial insulin, you basically give those remaining beta cells a break and they "rally" a bit and start working again. But over time, the process that destroyed the other beta cells will continue to destroy the remaining ones. So this little breather where you aren't on insulin probably won't last forever.

My daughter also came off insulin for a couple of months after diagnosis. We left the hospital needing 5 units of lantus a day and a tiny amount of bolus insulin for meals. We slowly had to drop the lantus all the way down to zero and it stayed there for a couple of months. But as the final beta cells died off, we slowly had to increase the basal insulin and it has done nothing but rise ever since. We currently use \~25-30 units of basal insulin a day.

The people saying shit don't understand what is going on and some of them never will. People like to be ignorant of facts for some reason. I would try to educate them a little, but at some point it isn't worth it and you should save your breath. Some people are especially unwilling to learn and accept that their position is wrong, so I just cut them out of my life entirely. I don't care if they are family or not. Willful ignorance is painful to deal with and I don't have time for that kind of stupidity.
I was on insulin my first 4 months, I’ve been off completely for almost a year.
"Not all my islet cells have been destroyed yet, it takes some time"
If your honeymoon is that extreme I highly reccomend looking into the DREAMT or TOPPLE study
wait wait wait…. You can be Type 1 and not be on insulin??

You body is currently killing off your beta cells, the cells that product insulin.  Having high blood sugar also kills off your beta cells, historically, most people were running on very high blood sugar for a very long time before they were diagnosed and effectively helped their immune system kill off there remaining beta cells.  

If you have your blood work handy from when you were diagnosed, look to see if you have GAD-65 Autoanitbody numbers.  The normal range for that antibody is 0-5, when I was diagnosed mine was 1500.  That should shut most people up when they say "you aren't diabetic", you can explain Type 1 is an autoimmune disease and its currently attacking your ability to produce insulin and we have no way of stopping it.
Ask them how their diabetes is going, then tell them to shut up and fuck off.

I was also diagnosed two months ago and told I was on a honeymoon phase since I don’t need much insulin. Got from 6 to 3 units for basal and most of the time no rapid (only for high carb/sugar meals and snacks). The way I explain it is just that my pancreas has still a little bit of strength to help me for now :)
Is it normal to have no honeymoon also? I’ve been on insulin since October with not much change in basal dose or bolus ratios?

claims: when you are first diagnosed your pancreas usually still has some beta cells left. but they are usually almost burned out because they were working in overdrive trying to keep your blood sugar in check. when you introduce artificial insulin, you basically give those remaining beta cells a break and they "rally" a bit and start working again. but over time, the process that destroyed the other beta cells will continue to destroy the remaining ones.
you body is currently killing off your beta cells, the cells that product insulin.  having high blood sugar also kills off your beta cells
type 1 is an autoimmune disease and its currently attacking your ability to produce insulin and we have no way of stopping it.
you body is currently killing off your beta cells, the cells that product insulin.

post:
How to get lower Blood Sugar levels before meals?
As you know Blood Sugar is important to maintain in the 80-130/150 range. I heard you shouldn't hit above 180 after you eat ideally. So how do I lower my blood sugars before I eat?

comments.text:
Well it starts off with having good sugar to start with. 

What also helped me combat this was pre-bolusing. Say I were to sit and eat rice and chicken and take my insulin right then and there, I’ll shoot up right after. However, If I take my insulin 10 minutes before, I start descending which then lets me to eat and keep my sugars stable.
Having the right amount of basal insulin to start with should help a lot.

Besides prebolusing long enough in advance and making sure your basal is right, as already mentioned? If it hasn't come back down to where you would prefer to have it before you eat yet, it should be totally fine to bolus a little extra to help cover the difference, for sort of a modified sliding scale type approach. I will do that sometimes, if I need to eat again sooner or the previous meal sent it up for longer than expected.

**Much** easier (and safer!) to judge appropriate timing and so forth with this stuff, if you do have CGM data to keep an eye on. Better when you can readily see when your blood sugar does start going down after a bolus, to start eating then. Definitely recommended for a useful overview: Steven Ponder's *Sugar Surfing*. Taking more that kind of approach has really helped get mine on a more even keel.
Pregame!! Check your levels an hour before, correct for your sugars. Bolus for your meal before you eat to cancel out the time it takes your insulin to kick in then check about 30-45 minutes after.
Some foods like that wonder white bread will spike your sugar much faster than insulin can lower it. Look up the Glycemic Index.

If I understand the question, you certainly can take correction doses as needed, and even wait for sugars to come down before eating/bolusing for food. Of course don't stack insulin or have too much lead time.

Here is an article shows how to lower your blood sugar levels.  
[https://facebook.santhosh.com/article/how-achieve-healthy-blood-sugar-levels](https://facebook.santhosh.com/article/how-achieve-healthy-blood-sugar-levels)

I tried intermittent fasting and followed the 16:8 and on TMAD or two meals a day. It's a slow process but guaranteed effective. I feel more energized even without eating rice or sweets. Because naturally when you are on intermittent fasting, your energy is fueled by your own fats. Still, I try not to deprive myself and still indulge in desserts that are keto approved. I must say that nutrition and lifestyle change greatly help. May I also add that GLUCONIZE helped me a lot too! It gave me customized solution to diabetes which I tried personally and it worked for me.

claims: and take my insulin right then and there, i’ll shoot up right after. however, if i take my insulin 10 minutes before, i start descending which then lets me to eat and keep my sugars stable.

prebolusing long enough in advance and making sure your basal is right, as already mentioned? if it hasn't come back down to where you would prefer to have it before you eat yet, it should be totally fine to bolus a little extra to help cover the difference, for sort of a modified sliding scale type approach.
having the right amount of basal insulin to start with should help a lot.
pregame!! check your levels an hour before, correct for your sugars. bolus for your meal before you eat to cancel out the time it takes your insulin to kick in then check about 30-45 minutes after.

post:
Can I do A1c bloodwork with low blood sugar?
Just woke up to get bloodwork done soonish - fasting for 10 hours. Blood sugar is low - 3.4 right now and falling. If I go to the clinic ASAP will they do my blood work with low blood sugar or can I consume anything that won’t affect my fast to raise my bg? Don’t have dex tabs rn. Thanks.

comments.text: Treat your low. It won’t really affect your a1c. It’s Ana average number over 90 days. Just take care of yourself now.
A1c isn’t a test you need to be fasting for. Treat the low!
You dont have to be fasting for just a1c. Definitely treat your low, your dr will understand.
I have taken it before with high blood sugar and my test for A1C still somehow came back in good standing. But please don't be doing anything with low blood sugar get that balanced please.
If people could lower their A1C by going into the Doctors office with low blood sugar, we'd all be cured!

HbA1c, or abbreviated A1c, is not just your average blood glucose of the last 90 days. It’s a little more complicated. It’s actually measuring how much your red blood cells are covered with a sugar layer. So, no even eating a whole meal before an A1c test shouldn’t raise your A1c. If I’m wrong here feel free to correct.

claims: treat your low. it won’t really affect your a1c. it’s ana average number over 90 days. just take care of yourself now.
treat your low. it won’t really affect your a1c.
a1c isn’t a test you need to be fasting for
i have taken it before with high blood sugar and my test for a1c still somehow came back in good standing. but please don't be doing anything with low blood sugar get that balanced please.

hba1c, or abbreviated a1c, is not just your average blood glucose of the last 90 days. it’s a little more complicated. it’s actually measuring how much your red blood cells are covered with a sugar layer. so, no even eating a whole meal before an a1c test shouldn’t raise your a1c.

post: How to help up my teenage neighbor who was just diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes?

comments.text: It seems impossible at the beginning. They have to process a lot of new information. An invaluable book we have is Type 1 Diabetes in children, adolescents, and young adults’ 7th edition. It is by Dr. Ragnar Hanas. I would hold off on the snacks. His diagnosis is centered around food and what is a good or bad choice. They have a lot to figure out. I think the best thing would be to just be available.
Diabetes Solution by Dr. Richard K Bernstein. Great teachings on how to properly cover meals and how to eat low carb. Best bet for ever getting a1c down to the low 5s range.

I’ve got a booklet I’ve written up, its basically all the stuff I wanted to know at diagnosis. I’m happy to send you a copy of it if you’d like to send it over to her.

Otherwise, “Think like a pancreas” “Bright Spots and Landmines” and “Sugar Surfing” are all excellent books. The Juicebox podcast is also great. 

Carbs&Cals app is great for calculating carb numbers.
Leave her alone
Here is a potentially useful article on type 1 as a teenager: http://www.dsolve.com/2016/06/09/what-can-you-expect-as-your-diabetic-child-goes-through-the-teenage-years/
Offering to be an emergency contact (outside of medical needs) would be helpful.  It's useful to have a trusted neighbor that is willing to help be a resource.

DO NOT GIVE FOOD. ESPECIALLY SUGAR FREE/LOW CARB FOOD! [A bag for his blood check kit](https://www.myabetic.com/collections/diabetes-cases/products/banting-diabetes-wallet?variant=2543054979098&gclid=CjwKCAjw1YCkBhAOEiwA5aN4AQHezENyy1fQ-BdfTyTGsjMaO8TGSwGwanHSg_ET8JDbsO7GiAwFBRoCbKgQAvD_BwE), cool medical ID bracelet. If He's on a pump/CGM there are [cool stickers](https://pumppeelz.com/) you can get to decorate them so they dont look so 'medical'
theyre your neighbors so just be neighborly unless they ask for specific help

claims: diabetes solution by dr. richard k bernstein. great teachings on how to properly cover meals and how to eat low carb. best bet for ever getting a1c down to the low 5s range.
diabetes solution by dr. richard k bernstein. great teachings on how to properly cover meals and how to eat low carb.
http://www.dsolve.com/2016/06/09/what-can-you-expect-as-your-diabetic-child-goes-through-the-teenage-years/
